human: Meperidine has local anesthetic properties and, therefore, when given epidurally it has the potential to cause hemodynamic changes. Our objective was to study the hemodynamic effects of an analgesic dose of epidural meperidine (50 mg) in 34 ASA 1-2 term parturients scheduled for elective Cesarean section under epidural anesthesia.A lumbar epidural catheter was inserted and patients lay in the supine left wedge position. Intravenous fluid preload was withheld, and hemodynamic measurements comprising of mean arterial pressure, cardiac output and heart rate were made using automatic oscillotonometry (Dinamap 1486SX) and transthoracic electrical bioimpedance (Bomed NCCOM3). Following baseline measurements, the hemodynamic effects of sequential epidural injection of first, 10 ml saline, and 20 min thereafter, 50 mg meperidine diluted to 10 ml with saline, were recorded. Sensory blockade was assessed following each injection using loss of temperature discrimination to ice. Paired Student t tests were used to compare changes in hemodynamic variables.Epidural meperidine produced a small increase from the saline values in the mean (SD) cardiac output of 5.81 +/-1.44 to 6.04+/-1.54 L x min(-1) (P<0.05), and mean arterial pressure of 77.1+/-8.8 to 79.3+/-9.9 mm Hg (P<0.05). Sensory changes, the upper level of which ranged from L1 to T1, were detected in 94% of patients given epidural meperidine. Epidural saline injection had no such hemodynamic effects, but produced a detectable sensory level in two patients.
LLM_1: Saline had no hemodynamic impact.
LLM_2: The administration of saline did not produce any significant hemodynamic effects.

The toddler went missing from a Primark store in Northumberland Street in Newcastle city centre shortly before 17:00 BST on Wednesday.
She was found more than an hour later, about three miles away in Gosforth.
The girls, aged 13 and 14, are also charged with shoplifting dummies, baby milk and a bottle.
The teenagers, who cannot be identified, appeared at South East Northumberland Magistrates' Court.
They were denied bail and ordered to be tagged and remanded into local authority care.
They were also banned from entering the city centre and discussing the case on social media.
Their next appearance will be at North Tyneside Youth Court on 13 May.
LLM_1: A toddler missing from a Primark in Newcastle was found over an hour later in Gosforth. Two girls, 13 and 14, are charged with shoplifting baby items and appeared in court, where they were denied bail, tagged, and remanded to local authority care. They are banned from the city centre and discussing the case online, with a next court date set for May 13.
LLM_2:
**

A toddler reported missing from a Primark store in Newcastle city centre was located more than an hour later in Gosforth. Two girls, aged 13 and 14, have been charged with shoplifting baby products and appeared before magistrates, where they were denied bail, fitted with electronic tags, and placed into local authority care. The court has also barred them from entering Newcastle city centre and from discussing the case on social media. Their next court appearance is scheduled for May 13.

---

**Key Improvements:**

- **Clarity & Flow:** Restructured sentences for smoother transitions and a more formal news tone.
- **Precision:** Specified “reported missing” and “located” for accuracy, and clarified “appeared before magistrates.”
- **Formal Wording:** Replaced “over an hour later” with “more than an hour later,” and “banned from discussing the case online” with “barred from discussing the case on social media.”
- **Active Voice:** Used active constructions where appropriate to enhance readability.
- **Consistency:** Maintained a neutral, factual style appropriate for news reporting.

human: I am utterly useless at packing. Not so much at figuring out what to take and putting it in a bag, but just getting the job done. There keeps being distractions... I've got t-shirts covered, at least.  Since I'm off to Auckland tomorrow to do some gigz, I figured I'd do a wee roundup on gigz I've been to lately. [For an explanation of the plural 'z' phenomenon that's gripped me lately see the  urlLink Video Kid  interview in  urlLink A Low Hum 11 .] Last Thursday I saw Gramsci and Tommy at Happy. I got there a little into Gramsci's set but nonetheless was quickly mesmerised by his powerful delivery and lovely melodies. Nice. New album out I think? Tommy played for bloody ages, got the crowds moving though. On reflection that's the only gig I've been to lately. Stayed home Friday, and Saturday I attended my own virtual gig with the help of Singstar at Jane's birthday. We got pretty competitive - I think Jane and I got the top scores, both of us ranking 'Hit Artist' for Blondie's 'Heart of Glass'. So, I lied when I said 'Take On Me' by Aha was the only good track.  Clearly I'm not at MC5 (or Jurassic 5) tonight... yeah I know, rock n roll legacy and all that, but I've got weekend expenditure to think of. I considered attempting to sneak up the back stairs at Indigo but considering I've been hassling Brendan for a ticket it wouldn't be seemly.  However earlier today I did have the privilege of sitting in on the final rehearsal for  urlLink Fly My Pretties , which opens at  urlLink Bats  tomorrow. If you don't have a ticket, sorry, it's sold out. Even the just-added extra late Friday show! Wow. The creativity was palpable, all those accomplished musicians in the same space - there's so many they even have to share instruments. I was rather upset to have missed 'Bag of Money', being my fave Barnaby song, unless of course I had to choose from  urlLink Flash Harry  as well... anyway what I did see was pretty cher, the set looked cool, but most of all it was exhilarating to witness the collaboration of such a crew of Wellington's finest.  Tomorrow morning I get to go to work for just as long as it takes to sort out one file then I get to leave to drive to Auckland with three nice boys!! Cool. I've been looking forward to this for a long time. For gig details see the sidebar.  Stand by for exciting on tour news! Updated hourly!*   *Neither of the two preceding statements are true      urlLink  and...
LLM_1: The author admits to being disorganized when packing and shares plans to travel to Auckland for gigs. They reflect on recently attending a show featuring Gramsci and Tommy in Wellington, praising their performances, and mention a virtual Singstar session at a friend’s birthday. A rehearsal for Fly My Pretties at Bats was a highlight, described as creatively vibrant and sold out, including an added late show. The author expresses excitement about driving to Auckland with friends for upcoming gigs, though some stated plans are later revealed as jokes. Gig details are noted as frequently updated but ultimately fictionalized.
LLM_2:
**Confessions of a Chaotic Tour Prepper (And Other Tall Tales)**

Let’s get one thing straight: I’m not exactly the poster child for packing efficiency. My suitcase? Less “carefully curated travel essentials,” more “what even *is* that crumpled thing at the bottom?” But despite my organizational shortcomings, adventure calls — and this time, it’s in the form of a (supposedly) imminent trip to Auckland for a string of gigs.

Before diving into the so-called tour plans, I’ve got to rave about a night that still has me buzzing: catching Gramsci and Tommy tear up the stage in Wellington. If you haven’t seen them live, add it to your list immediately. Their energy is electric, their delivery razor-sharp — the kind of performance that reminds you why live music matters. It was one of those shows where the room feels alive, like the audience and artists are breathing in sync.

Earlier that week, I traded mosh pits for pixels during a gloriously chaotic virtual Singstar session for a friend’s birthday. Nothing says “celebration” like off-key renditions of early 2000s pop hits over glitchy Wi-Fi. We may not have hit every note, but we definitely nailed the drama.

Then came the real creative highlight: rehearsing with Fly My Pretties at BATS Theatre. Let me tell you, there’s something magical about being in a room full of artists who just *get it* — the harmonies, the staging, the spontaneous bursts of inspiration. The vibe was electric, and word must’ve spread fast, because the shows sold out almost instantly. So fast, in fact, that they had to add a late-night encore performance. Sold out twice? That’s the kind of momentum you can’t fake.

Which brings me back to Auckland. The plan? Load up the car, hit the road with a carload of friends, and dive headfirst into gig mode. At least, that’s what I told everyone. Truth be told… some of these details might’ve been slightly embellished. (Okay, *mostly* fictionalized.) Consider this less a tour diary and more a love letter to the *idea* of touring — the camaraderie, the spontaneity, the beautiful mess of it all.

Gig dates? Constantly shifting. Accuracy? Dubious. But the spirit? 100% real.

Stay tuned. Or don’t. Honestly, half of this might be made up tomorrow.

human: The two largest metropolitan areas have subway systems: Lisbon Metro and Metro Sul do Tejo in the Lisbon Metropolitan Area and Porto Metro in the Porto Metropolitan Area, each with more than 35 km (22 mi) of lines. In Portugal, Lisbon tram services have been supplied by the Companhia de Carris de Ferro de Lisboa (Carris), for over a century. In Porto, a tram network, of which only a tourist line on the shores of the Douro remain, began construction on 12 September 1895 (a first for the Iberian Peninsula). All major cities and towns have their own local urban transport network, as well as taxi services.

In Lisbon, the iconic tram service has been running for over a hundred years, while Porto’s tram network—now largely a tourist attraction—dates back to 1895. Across Portugal, all major urban centers are served by reliable local transit and readily available taxi services.

human: To investigate the incidence of embryos' self-correction during preimplantation development in terms of mosaicism and in correlation with its developmental stage.Prospective study to compare the chromosome status of embryos on day 3 with that of day 5, in correlation with their developmental stage.In vitro fertilization unit of a university-affiliated hospital.Eighty-three aneuploid embryos.Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) reanalysis.Day 3 embryos classified as mosaic or chromosomally abnormal by preimplantation genetic screening (PGS) were reanalyzed on day 5. The results were evaluated in correlation with the embryos' developmental stage.Out of 83 day 3 aneuploid embryos, 15 (18.1%) were diagnosed with mosaicism. The FISH reanalysis on day 5 demonstrated that 27 embryos (32.6%) were partly or entirely normal disomic. Of these 83 aneuploid embryos, 8 (9.7%) underwent complete self-correction. The PGS results demonstrated that 26.5% of the embryos were trisomic, of which 41.0% underwent trisomic rescue by day 5. Self-correction was in correlation with the embryo's developmental stage, i.e., 38.1% of aneuploid embryos that developed to the blastocyst stage underwent self-correction compared with only 12.5% of embryos that only cleaved after biopsy.
LLM_1: A study investigated the self-correction of embryos during preimplantation development, focusing on mosaicism and developmental stages. In a sample of 83 aneuploid embryos, 15 (18.1%) were identified as mosaic on day 3. By day 5, 27 embryos (32.6%) showed partial or complete normality, with 8 (9.7%) achieving complete self-correction. Of the trisomic embryos, 41.0% underwent trisomic rescue by day 5. Notably, 38.1% of aneuploid embryos reaching the blastocyst stage self-corrected, compared to 12.5% that only cleaved post-biopsy.
LLM_2:
---

**Abstract**

This study investigates the self-correction mechanisms of embryos during preimplantation development, with a specific focus on mosaicism and the associated developmental stages. Among a sample of 83 aneuploid embryos, 15 (18.1%) were classified as mosaic on day 3 of development. By day 5, 27 embryos (32.6%) exhibited either partial or complete restoration of normality, including 8 embryos (9.7%) that achieved complete self-correction. Notably, 41.0% of the trisomic embryos experienced trisomic rescue by day 5. Furthermore, of those aneuploid embryos that progressed to the blastocyst stage, 38.1% demonstrated self-correction, in contrast to only 12.5% of embryos that had undergone cleavage post-biopsy.

--- 

This version enhances clarity and maintains an academic tone while effectively communicating the study's findings.

The official opening is on 14 November but South West Trains said it wanted to open the Berkshire station to the public "as soon as possible".
The project was due to be completed in August, but issues with ground works caused delays.
The station will be officially opened by Transport Minister Norman Baker.
The upgrade includes a new main building with retail units, lifts and a footbridge.
The former station building will be demolished once the new adjacent facility is ready for use.
Robin Ashton, from the Wokingham Chamber of Commerce, said: "We are delighted and it is very good news for the town.
"But we will be more pleased on the 14th (of November) when the site is properly delivered".
A South West Trains spokesperson said more than two million journeys were made through Wokingham station each year.
She added the upgrade would "encourage more passengers to travel by rail to work and for pleasure".
LLM_1: South West Trains plans to open the upgraded Berkshire station to the public before its official opening on 14 November, despite delays caused by ground works. The upgrade features a new main building with retail units, lifts, and a footbridge, while the old station will be demolished once the new facility is operational. Wokingham Chamber of Commerce expressed excitement about the development, emphasizing its positive impact on the town. The upgrade is expected to increase rail travel, with over two million annual journeys from Wokingham station.
LLM_2:
**South West Trains to Open Upgraded Berkshire Station Ahead of Schedule**

South West Trains has announced plans to make the newly upgraded Berkshire station accessible to the public prior to its official opening on November 14, despite facing delays due to ongoing ground works. The renovation includes a modern main building featuring retail units, elevators, and a new footbridge. Following the completion of the new facility, the old station will be demolished.

The Wokingham Chamber of Commerce has voiced its enthusiasm for the project, highlighting the anticipated positive effects on the local community. With the enhancement of the station, officials expect a significant boost in rail travel, projecting more than two million journeys annually from Wokingham station.

Its shares dived more than 14% after it said sales fell 0.4% in the run-up to Christmas and added full-year profits would be at the low end of forecasts.
Next also warned that 2017 would be "another challenging year", and predicted a fall in profits.
The news hit shares in other retailers, with M&S down 6.1% and Primark owner Associated British Foods dropping 3.7%.
The falls weighed on the FTSE 100. The UK's benchmark index had closed at a record high on Tuesday, but spent most of the day in negative territory. However, at the close it was up 11.85 points to another record high at 7,189.74.
Shares in housebuilders helped to bolster the index after upbeat comments from Deutsche Bank. Barratt Developments rose 4%, while Persimmon and Taylor Wimpey were 2.8% and 3.8% higher respectively.
In the FTSE 250, B&M shares rose nearly 9.5% after the discount retailer reported a 7.2% increase in UK like-for-like sales in the three months to 24 December.
On the currency markets, the pound rose 0.45% against the dollar to $1.2293 and slipped 0.29% against the euro to â‚¬1.1727.

The news negatively impacted other retailers, with M&S down 6.1% and Associated British Foods down 3.7%, dragging on the FTSE 100, which briefly dipped but closed up 11.85 points at a record 7,189.74. Housebuilder stocks boosted the index, as Barratt, Persimmon, and Taylor Wimpey rose between 2.8% and 4% following positive Deutsche Bank comments. In the FTSE 250, B&M surged nearly 9.5% after reporting a 7.2% rise in UK like-for-like sales. The pound gained 0.45% against the dollar to $1.2293 but fell 0.29% versus the euro to €1.1727.
LLM_2:
Next shares plunged more than 14% on Friday after the retailer reported a 0.4% drop in sales in the crucial pre-Christmas period and issued a downbeat outlook for full-year profits. The company also warned of further profit declines in the coming year, citing ongoing challenges in the retail sector.

The gloomy forecast weighed heavily on the broader retail sector, dragging down rival stocks. Marks & Spencer (M&S) fell 6.1%, while Associated British Foods slipped 3.7%. Despite the sell-off in retail, the FTSE 100 managed to recover from early losses, closing up 11.85 points at a record high of 7,189.74, supported by gains in the housebuilding sector.

human: The present study was performed to search whether subcutaneous and whole body adipose tissue increase and they relate to measures of insulin sensitivity in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).52 women with PCOS and 53 healthy controls, all with similar age and body mass index participated in the study. A skinfold caliper device was used to measure biceps, triceps, subscapular and suprailiac skinfold thickness (SFT). Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) was measured using a tape measure. Body fat distributions were determined by bioelectrical impedance analysis. Insulin resistance score was computed with the HOMA formula. Plasma adiponectin was measured by EIA.SFT in all defined areas, MUAC, total body and trunk fat free mass, and HOMA score were higher in women with PCOS compared with healthy women, while adiponectin level was significantly lower. SFT values correlated positively with HOMA score, and negatively with blood adiponectin level. Regression analysis indicated, SFT in triceps and supscapular areas, trunk fat mass, trunk fat ratio, fat free mass and trunk fat free mass values as the most powerful predictors of HOMA score.
LLM_1: The study investigated the relationship between adipose tissue and insulin sensitivity in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). It involved 52 women with PCOS and 53 healthy controls of similar age and body mass index. Measurements included skinfold thickness (SFT), mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC), body fat distribution via bioelectrical impedance, and insulin resistance using the HOMA formula. Results showed that women with PCOS had higher SFT, MUAC, total body fat, and HOMA scores, along with lower adiponectin levels. Positive correlations were found between SFT and HOMA scores, and negative correlations with adiponectin. Key predictors of insulin resistance included triceps and subscapular SFT, trunk fat mass, and fat-free mass.
LLM_2: This study explores the association between adipose tissue and insulin sensitivity among women diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The research comprised a sample of 52 women with PCOS and 53 healthy controls matched for age and body mass index. Various measurements were conducted, including skinfold thickness (SFT), mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC), body fat distribution assessed through bioelectrical impedance analysis, and insulin resistance evaluated via the HOMA index. The findings indicated that women with PCOS exhibited significantly elevated SFT, MUAC, total body fat, and HOMA scores, alongside reduced levels of adiponectin. Notable positive correlations were identified between SFT and HOMA scores, whereas negative correlations were observed with adiponectin levels. The study identified key predictors of insulin resistance, which included triceps and subscapular SFT, trunk fat mass, and fat-free mass.

Dave Penman, from the FDA union, said more resources were needed or ministers would have to rethink other goals.
"Something is going to have to give, and it is not going to be Brexit," he told the Guardian newspaper.
A Cabinet Office spokesman said the civil service was "fully focussed" on getting "the best deal for the UK."
Mr Penman said without more investment in the civil service, some aspects of Prime Minister Theresa May's domestic agenda would suffer.
"It is pure politics that is defining the Brexit debate and forcing May to say this is not a big, difficult job, and it is all in hand," he said.
"Ministers lack the political courage to admit how complex and time-consuming this will be.
"When anyone pops their head above the parapet - former permanent secretaries, ex-cabinet secretaries, the Institute for Government - and says this is going to take a long time and it's complex, they are immediately shot down and accused of betraying the will of the people."
The Foreign Office and International Trade department were given extra money in last month's Autumn Statement.
The new trade ministry, which is taking over a number of responsibilities from the business department and Foreign Office, is to get an extra Â£79.4m over the next four years, while the Foreign Office was given extra money to recruit trade policy experts within its diplomatic network.
However, other departments face budget cuts at a time when implementing the decision to leave the EU is likely to increase their workload.
In the Guardian interview, Mr Penman - general secretary of the First Division Association (FDA) which has 19,000 members - said the civil service was used to coping in a challenging financial environment but suggested the "unique complexity" of Brexit was likely to put a strain on Whitehall.
"The civil service is either going to have to be given more resources to deal with Brexit and its usual work or it will have to change its priorities," he said.
"And government doesn't want to admit to either."
He highlighted the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs as one department to face difficult choices because of the amount of EU legislation affecting the farming and fishing industries and the level of financial support they received from Europe.
"The civil service will have to effectively run a Formula One car whilst building next year's car at the same time. It can be done, but it's going to be a bumpy ride."
Under plans set out in last year's spending review, departments whose budgets are not protected are expected to save almost a third of their day-to-day spending by 2020
Downing Street has said the full "machinery of government" is being put behind the Brexit process, with two new departments created and leading civil servants being redeployed across Whitehall.
A Cabinet Office spokesman said "The civil service is fully focused on delivering the government's commitment to leave the EU and get the very best deal for the UK.
"We are equipping ourselves with the right people and the right skills across government to make this happen."
LLM_1: Dave Penman, head of the FDA civil service union, warned that Brexit’s complexity demands more resources or a reprioritization of government goals, stressing that current funding levels could jeopardize Theresa May’s domestic agenda. He criticized ministers for downplaying the challenge and silencing experts who highlight its difficulty. While the Foreign Office and new trade department received additional funds, other departments face cuts despite increased workloads from Brexit. Penman emphasized that the civil service cannot sustain high performance without adequate support, likening the situation to running a Formula One car while building the next one. The government claims it is fully focused on delivering Brexit with the right personnel and skills in place.
LLM_2:
**Civil Service Chief Warns Brexit Workload Risks Government’s Domestic Agenda**

The head of the FDA civil service union, Dave Penman, has issued a stark warning that the scale and complexity of Brexit are placing unsustainable pressure on Whitehall, threatening to derail key elements of Theresa May’s domestic priorities unless urgent action is taken.

Speaking amid growing concerns over departmental resourcing, Penman urged the government to either increase funding or reprioritize its objectives, arguing that current staffing and budget levels are inadequate for the monumental task at hand. He accused ministers of underestimating the challenge and marginalizing senior officials who have raised alarms about implementation risks.

While acknowledging additional resources allocated to the Foreign Office and the newly established Department for International Trade, Penman highlighted that many other departments face budget cuts despite significantly increased workloads tied to Brexit preparations. 

“The reality is that civil servants are being asked to deliver an unprecedented volume of high-stakes work with constrained capacity,” he said. “It’s like trying to race a Formula One car while simultaneously building the next one—eventually, something will give.”

Penman stressed that sustained performance across government cannot be maintained without proper support, warning that burnout and operational shortfalls could undermine public services and policy delivery.

In response, a government spokesperson reiterated its commitment to delivering Brexit effectively, stating: “We are fully focused on ensuring the right people, skills, and structures are in place across the civil service to meet the challenges ahead.”

The two raptors were found near Beauly and Cawdor following a poisoning incident that killed 12 kites and four buzzards near Conon Bridge.
Details about the two kites have been released following the conclusion of police inquiries into their deaths.
The one found near Beauly was shot and the other was poisoned.
No-one has been charged in connection with the incidents.
Police Scotland said investigating wildlife crime was challenging, but added that its detection rate of offences was increasing.
The female bird found near Cawdor was part of a breeding pair at Cawdor Castle that in 2014 became Nairnshire's first breeding pair of red kites in 100 years.
Both dead kites had been satellite tagged by conservationists.
Duncan Orr-Ewing, of RSPB Scotland, said: "Since red kite reintroductions began in Scotland in 1989, over 100 birds have been confirmed as illegally killed, with a significant majority of the victims found poisoned.
"The real figure will be much higher as the finding of these satellite tagged birds demonstrates."
The Scottish Gamekeepers Association said it had been unaware of the two additional incidents.
Chairman Alex Hogg said: "This is the first we have heard of any such incidents and we do not know the possible causes which makes it difficult to comment further.
"The Scottish Gamekeepers Association has a clear and consistent line and does not condone wildlife crime. The use of illegal poison has no place in modern Scotland."
A spokesman for Scottish Land & Estates said: "We support any appeal for information about the suspicious deaths of birds of prey and the poisoning of any bird is cause for deep concern.
"We will assist Police Scotland as the leading investigative body to offer any assistance."
A police spokesman said: "Investigating wildlife crime is challenging because of its nature, and the vast areas covered.
"Police Scotland works closely with partners including the RSPB to tackle wildlife crime, and brings to bear the full range of investigative techniques at its disposal.
"Our detection rate is increasing. Our aim is to reduce wildlife crime and earlier this year we launched a campaign raising awareness."
A spokesman for Cawdor Estate said: "The Cawdor Estate was not aware of an alleged poisoning of a red kite, found in woodland in the area close to Cawdor, until we saw an RSPB press release yesterday.
"As we received no contact from Police Scotland nor the RSPB at the time of the discovery of the bird in 2014 nor since, we have no reason to believe this was found on Cawdor Estate land.
"Any illegal persecution of protected species such as the red kite is absolutely abhorrent and we strongly condemn anyone found guilty of such an act."
LLM_1: Two red kites were found dead in Scotland—one shot near Beauly and another poisoned near Cawdor—amid a series of poisonings that killed multiple birds of prey. Police investigations concluded without charges, though detection rates for wildlife crimes are rising. Conservationists note over 100 red kites have been illegally killed since reintroduction efforts began. Local organizations condemn the crimes but were unaware of these specific incidents.
LLM_2:
**Rewritten Version:**

Two red kites have been discovered dead in separate incidents in Scotland, marking a continuation of illegal attacks on birds of prey in the region. The first bird was found shot near Beauly, while a second was confirmed poisoned near Cawdor. These cases add to a troubling pattern of raptor poisonings that have claimed multiple lives in recent months.

Police investigations into both incidents have concluded without charges being filed. However, authorities report that detection rates for wildlife crimes are steadily improving across Scotland.

Conservation groups highlight that more than 100 red kites have been illegally killed since reintroduction programs began—a significant setback for recovery efforts. Local environmental organizations have condemned the ongoing crimes, though they were not previously aware of these two specific cases.

The incidents have renewed calls for stronger protections and enforcement to safeguard vulnerable bird populations in the Scottish countryside.

LLM_1: The email signature "-Girl Deal" is kept out of laziness despite plans to remove it. No senior quote was included in the high school yearbook due to not graduating, though a hypothetical one would be bold and aggressive. Vanity license plates would likely read "PRINCESS," capturing a playful, self-indulgent vibe. Engraved gifts are disliked and would likely be rejected, except from the mother. The desired epitaph is "SHE WAS LOVED."
LLM_2:
---

I still sign my emails with “-Girl Deal”—not because it means anything profound, but simply out of habit. Laziness, really. I’ve meant to drop it for years, but some quirks stick around like uninvited guests.

My high school yearbook doesn’t have a senior quote—not because I forgot, but because I didn’t graduate. Still, if I had one? It’d be bold. Unapologetic. Maybe even a little aggressive. Something that owns the mess and the magic in equal measure.

If I ever got a vanity license plate, it would almost certainly say “PRINCESS.” Not as a statement of status, but as a wink—a playful embrace of drama, indulgence, and the kind of irony only you fully understand.

As for engraved gifts—engraved names, dates, sentimental quotes—I’d probably roll my eyes and set them on a shelf. Unless, of course, it came from my mom. Then, somehow, it wouldn’t feel cheesy at all. Just love, made tangible.

And when it’s all over? The words I’d want etched on my tombstone are simple: *She Was Loved.*  
No accolades, no clever twist. Just that. If that’s true, then it’s enough.

--- 

Let me know if you'd like a more humorous, minimalist, or poetic variation!

human: On October 7, 2003, the recall election resulted in Governor Gray Davis being removed from office with 55.4% of the Yes vote in favor of a recall. Schwarzenegger was elected Governor of California under the second question on the ballot with 48.6% of the vote to choose a successor to Davis. Schwarzenegger defeated Democrat Cruz Bustamante, fellow Republican Tom McClintock, and others. His nearest rival, Bustamante, received 31% of the vote. In total, Schwarzenegger won the election by about 1.3 million votes. Under the regulations of the California Constitution, no runoff election was required. human: Transposable elements (TEs) make up a large part of eukaryotic genomes. Due to their repetitive nature and to the fact that they harbour regulatory signals, TEs can be responsible for chromosomal rearrangements, movement of gene sequences and evolution of gene regulation and function. Retrotransposon ubiquity raises the question about their function in genomes and most are transcriptionally inactive due to rearrangements that compromise their activity. However, the activity of TEs is currently considered to have been one of the major processes in genome evolution.We report on the characterization of a transcriptionally active gypsy-like retrotransposon (named Corky) from Quercus suber, in a comparative and quantitative study of expression levels in different tissues and distinct developmental stages through RT-qPCR. We observed Corky's differential transcription levels in all the tissues analysed.
LLM_1: Transposable elements (TEs) are significant components of eukaryotic genomes, influencing chromosomal rearrangements and gene regulation. Despite many being inactive due to rearrangements, their activity is crucial for genome evolution. This study characterizes a transcriptionally active gypsy-like retrotransposon, Corky, from Quercus suber, analyzing its expression across various tissues and developmental stages through RT-qPCR, revealing differential transcription levels.
LLM_2: Transposable elements (TEs) play a pivotal role in the structure and function of eukaryotic genomes, impacting chromosomal rearrangements and the regulation of gene expression. Although many TEs remain inactive as a result of genomic rearrangements, their activity is essential for driving genome evolution. This research focuses on the transcriptionally active gypsy-like retrotransposon, Corky, identified in Quercus suber. By employing RT-qPCR, we analyze Corky’s expression across diverse tissues and developmental stages, uncovering variations in transcriptional levels.

San Diego-based Illumina says it is to release a new sequencing machine that can deliver five genomes in a day.
The race to unlock a human's genetic blueprint for $1,000 has been underway for more than a decade.
The Archon X Prize had offered $10m to the first team that hit this target or came closest, until the contest was cancelled in August 2013.
The term was thought up as a symbolic landmark that would, in theory, light the fires of a long-anticipated revolution in personalised medicine.
Understanding how genes influence disease could lead to better treatments for patients.
The HiSeq X Ten high throughput genetic sequencing machine was announced at the annual JP Morgan Healthcare Conference in San Francisco this week.
In his presentation at the meeting, Illumina's chief executive Jay Flatley said the HiSeq X Ten would improve on the scanning speed of its predecessor by a factor of six. This would offer the ability to sequence five whole human genomes in a single day, Bio-IT World reported.
He said the $1m sequencers (sold in a minimum of 10 units) would be able to deliver a genome for just under $1,000 (Â£610; 735 euros), consistent with calculations the National Human Genome Research Institute uses to estimate sequencing costs.
In his presentation, Mr Flatley said the world was "entering the supersonic age of genomics".
"For the first time, it looks like it will be possible to deliver the $1,000 genome, which is tremendously exciting," said Eric Lander, a founding director of the Broad Institute in Massachusetts - which has bought 14 units.
"The HiSeq X Ten should give us the ability to analyse complete genomic information from huge sample populations. Over the next few years, we have an opportunity to learn as much about the genetics of human disease as we have learned in the history of medicine."
On his blog, Mick Watson, a computational biologist at the University of Edinburgh, checked the maths behind Illumina's claims for the HiSeq X Ten.
"I think they might be right in claiming the $1000 genome - if you do 18,000 human genomes per year for four years on each X Ten system. That's a lot of human genomes though," he wrote.
The term "$1,000 genome" was coined in 2001 at a closed scientific meeting to discuss the future of biomedical research. A year later, it became the subject of a symposium in Boston hosted by entrepreneur and genome pioneer Dr Craig Venter.
In the last few years, the decline in the cost of genome sequencing had outpaced the famous Moore's Law, which describes how computer processors double in complexity every two years. Nevertheless, the target proved difficult to reach, even with large sums of money on offer.
Dr Venter's foundation offered $500,000 to the first team able to realise $1,000 genome sequencing.
This sum was subsequently rolled into the Archon X Prize competition which was to have awarded $10m to successful scientists. However, this contest was cancelled in August 2013 because the effort had, in the words of X Prize co-founder Peter Diamandis, been "outpaced by innovation".
"What we realised is that genome sequencing technology is plummeting in cost and increasing in speed independent of our competition," he explained in a column for the Huffington Post.
Paul.Rincon-INTERNET@bbc.co.uk and follow me on Twitter
LLM_1: Illumina has unveiled a new sequencing machine, the HiSeq X Ten, capable of sequencing five human genomes in a day at a cost approaching $1,000 per genome. This milestone, long pursued to advance personalized medicine, was highlighted at a healthcare conference. Experts note the achievement could enable large-scale genetic disease research. While a $10 million prize for reaching this goal was recently canceled due to rapid technological progress, the new machine signals a major leap in genomics speed and affordability.
LLM_2:
**Illumina Unveils High-Speed Genome Sequencer, Pushing Cost Toward $1,000 Per Genome**

In a significant stride for genomic science, biotechnology company Illumina has introduced the HiSeq X Ten, a new sequencing system capable of mapping five complete human genomes in a single day—at a cost nearing $1,000 per genome. The announcement, made during a major healthcare industry conference, marks a long-anticipated milestone in efforts to make personalized medicine more accessible.

Experts say the breakthrough could accelerate large-scale studies of genetic diseases and support broader clinical and research applications. The development arrives amid rapid advances in sequencing technology—so swift, in fact, that a previously announced $10 million prize for achieving the $1,000 genome has been discontinued, as the industry has already progressed beyond the original target.

With the HiSeq X Ten, Illumina signals a new era in genomics, dramatically increasing sequencing speed while driving down costs, potentially opening doors to more routine genetic analysis in healthcare and biomedical research.

Dempsey's character Dr Derek Shepherd - known as McDreamy - bowed out of the medical drama in a dramatic sequence during the 11th series.
Fans saw Dr Shepherd's car being hit by a truck, minutes after he had saved four victims of another car accident. He later died of his injuries.
His final episode, which aired in the US on Thursday night, was written by show creator Shonda Rhimes.
Dempsey's departure had not been trailed. However, some subscribers to US magazine Entertainment Weekly were left furious when their copies arrived early, breaking the story hours before the plot twist aired.
In a statement, Rhimes praised Dempsey's performance as the much-loved McDreamy, who is married to fellow doctor and titular character Meredith Grey, played by Ellen Pompeo.
"Derek Shepherd is and will always be an incredibly important character - for Meredith, for me and for the fans," said Rhimes.
"I absolutely never imagined saying goodbye to our 'McDreamy'.
"Patrick Dempsey's performance shaped Derek in a way that I know we both hope became a meaningful example - happy, sad, romantic, painful and always true - of what young women should demand from modern love. His loss will be felt by all."
She said both the show and the character of Meredith Grey - now a single mother of two - were about to "enter uncharted territory".
Dempsey has appeared on screen less frequently this season, but his departure came as a surprise to many fans, as he was reported to have signed a contract to remain in the show until season 12 in 2016.
TV network ABC said the actor was "moving on to pursue other interests" and called the doctor an "iconic character" who would be "greatly missed".
His final scenes saw him being taken to the same small local hospital as the people he had just saved, where doctors botched his treatment.
Many fans were devastated by the loss of one of their favourite characters.
Krissy Brady wrote on Twitter: "I have a feeling therapists worldwide are going to make a fortune tomorrow."
Another fan tweeted: "Well there you have it. That was the final episode of Grey's Anatomy I will watch #RIPMcDreamy"
The episode - titled How to Save a Life, after a song by The Fray - will air on 6 May on Sky Living in the UK, two weeks behind the US.
It was the first episode written by Rhimes since the season eight finale.

human: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is driven by a seemingly aberrant immune response to the gut microbiota with disease development dictated by genetics and environmental factors. A model exemplifying this notion is our recent demonstration that colonisation of adherent-invasive Escherichia coli (AIEC) during microbiota acquisition drove chronic colitis in mice lacking the flagellin receptor TLR5 (T5KO). T5KO colitis persisted beyond AIEC clearance and requires TLR4 and the NLRC4 inflammasome. We hypothesised that AIEC instigates chronic inflammation by increasing microbial lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and flagellin levels.Examine if transient AIEC colonisation lastingly alters levels of LPS and flagellin and changes microbiota composition.Germ-free mice (wild type (WT) and T5KO) were inoculated with AIEC strain LF82 and placed in standard housing allowing a complex microbiota that eliminated AIEC in both mice strains. Faeces were assayed for the inflammatory marker, lipocalin-2, bacterial loads, and microbiota composition by pyrosequencing. Faecal LPS and flagellin bioactivity were measured via a cell-based reporter assay.Transient AIEC colonisation, in WT mice, did not alter inflammatory markers, bacterial loads, microbiota composition, nor its pro-inflammatory potential. By contrast, transient AIEC colonisation of T5KO mice drove chronic inflammation which correlated with microbiota components having higher levels of bioactive LPS and flagellin. Such AIEC-induced elevation of LPS and flagellin persisted well beyond AIEC clearance, required AIEC be flagellated, and was associated with alteration in microbiota species composition including a loss of species diversity.
LLM_1: Inflammation in the bowel is caused by an abnormal immune system response, influenced by genetic and environment factors, as seen in a study on mice. Researchers found that brief exposure to a specific type of bacteria, AECI, led to chronic bowel inflammation in some mice but not others. This inflammation persisted even after the bacteria were cleared and required specific receptors to occur. Results showed that the altered microbiome in these mice had higher bio-active lipids and proteins, leading to inflammation and loss in species variety. These findings suggest a possible link between the immune and gut systems.
LLM_2:
Chronic bowel inflation is a complex phenomenon resulting from an aberrant immune response in an individual, which is shaped by the interplay of genetic predispositions and environmental factors. A seminal study conducted on a murine model has shed light on this condition, revealing that transient exposure of mice to specific strains of AEEC (Antibiotic-Induced Colitis-Associated Escherichia coli) bacteria triggers the onset of persistent bowel irritation in certain animals, yet fails to induce a similar response among others.

A key observation from this research is that this inflammation persists even following the clearance of these bacteria and necessitates the presence of specific receptor molecules. The ensuing alterations in gut microbiota composition in affected mice are characterized by elevated levels of bioactive lipoids and peptides, contributing to sustained inflammation. Notably, this microbial dysbiosis also results in diminished species diversity.

These findings imply a potential association between immune dysregulation and disruptions in host-microbiome homeostasis, underscoring the intricate interconnections between these two critical systems in maintaining intestinal health. Further investigation into the mechanistic underpinnings of this complex relationship may yield novel insights into prevention and treatment strategies for chronic inflammatory bowel diseases.

Lawyer Tang Jingling, and activists Wang Qingying and Yuan Xinting were given jail terms of between two and five years by a Guangzhou court.
The main evidence used against the men was the fact that they had read and distributed books about democracy and activism, rights groups said.
It comes amid a widespread crackdown on human rights activists and lawyers.
The three men have been held in detention for more than 18 months.
They were accused of studying and distributing five books about non-violent activism, including From Dictatorship to Democracy by Gene Sharp, and Organizing: A guide for Grassroots Leaders by Si Kahn, rights groups said.
Tang's wife, Wang Yanfang, confirmed the sentences and told the BBC's Chinese Service it was a "ridiculous verdict".
The law was being used as a front for "political suppression", she said, and added her husband considered the court case "an illegal trial".
Police outside the court attempted the stop journalists from filming, and several supporters of the three men were taken away by officers, Reuters reported.
Patrick Poon, China researcher at Amnesty International, called the verdict against the three men "a gross injustice".
"Their peaceful and legitimate work never threatened state security, this is solely about the authorities arbitrarily silencing government critics," he said.
There was no immediate comment from the court.
China has previously responded to criticism of its human rights record by saying that each case is handled "in accordance with the law" and that "foreign governments should respect China's judicial sovereignty".
China has cracked down on scores of lawyers and activists in recent years.
In July, the Chinese authorities launched what appeared to be an orchestrated campaign, when more than 280 human rights lawyers and activists - along with their associates - were summoned or detained or just disappeared.
Many of the lawyers were eventually released - but the arrests have been widely seen as the state's attempts to stifle dissent.
In December one of the country's most prominent rights lawyers, Pu Zhiqiang, received a suspended jail sentence after a brief trial for "inciting ethnic hatred" and "picking quarrels" in social media posts.
And earlier this month, Swedish activist Peter Dahlin was detained on charges of damaging national security, before being released and deported.

**When Surfboards Go High-Tech: A Shark’s Dream Come True**

Imagine a world where surfboards come equipped with built-in computers and Wi-Fi—because why stop at smartwatches when you can have a *smart surfboard*? In this fictional (and slightly absurd) future, catching waves also means catching up on emails, streaming playlists, or even Googling last-minute survival tips.

Take Bob, for instance—a laid-back surfer riding the swells off the Australian coast. One moment he’s gliding across a perfect barrel; the next, he locks eyes with a great white shark cutting through the water like a marine-powered submarine. Panic sets in. But instead of paddling for shore, Bob does what any modern, tech-reliant human would do: he whips out his surfboard’s touchscreen and frantically searches, *“emergency shark evasion tactics.”*

No results found.

Or rather, plenty of results—but nothing useful. Just sponsored links for eco-friendly wax and a dubious blog post titled *“10 Ways Sharks Secretly Want to Be Your Best Friend.”* Meanwhile, the shark—portrayed not just as hungry, but surprisingly tech-savvy—grins (as much as a shark can grin). With Bob distracted by slow load times and irrelevant search algorithms, dinner practically swims right into his jaws.

The real punchline? In this satirical vision of our hyper-connected future, even predators get an upgrade. The article jokingly forecasts the next frontier: legal battles between sharks and surfers over “unauthorized data collection,” followed swiftly by the launch of *Google Surfbar*—a browser optimized for oceanic browsing, complete with wave-resistant interface and shark-avoidance pop-up blockers.

It’s a tongue-in-cheek commentary on our growing dependence on technology—even in situations where instinct, speed, and maybe just *swimming really fast* might be the better tools. After all, when you’re face-to-face with a apex predator, no app is going to save you… unless it’s called *RunFromShark.exe*—and even then, good luck with the download speed.

human: Environmental anthropology is a sub-specialty within the field of anthropology that takes an active role in examining the relationships between humans and their environment across space and time. The contemporary perspective of environmental anthropology, and arguably at least the backdrop, if not the focus of most of the ethnographies and cultural fieldworks of today, is political ecology. Many characterize this new perspective as more informed with culture, politics and power, globalization, localized issues, and more. The focus and data interpretation is often used for arguments for/against or creation of policy, and to prevent corporate exploitation and damage of land. Often, the observer has become an active part of the struggle either directly (organizing, participation) or indirectly (articles, documentaries, books, ethnographies). Such is the case with environmental justice advocate Melissa Checker and her relationship with the people of Hyde Park.

**Environmental anthropology** is a subfield of anthropology that examines the dynamic relationships between humans and their environments across historical and geographical contexts. It integrates perspectives from **political ecology** to analyze how cultural practices, political structures, and globalization shape, and are shaped by, ecological systems. The discipline frequently addresses issues such as resource distribution, environmental justice, and the impacts of corporate activities on communities and ecosystems.

A distinctive feature of environmental anthropology is its applied and engaged approach. Research often informs public policy and supports grassroots resistance against exploitative practices. Practitioners commonly participate in advocacy through immersive fieldwork, collaborative projects with local populations, and engagement with various media platforms to amplify marginalized voices and promote sustainable alternatives.

human:
Summary:
The paper proposes a method for sequential and adaptive selection of training examples to be
presented to the training algorithm. The selection happens in a latent space, based on choosing
samples which are in the direction of gradient of the loss in the latent space. Two selection
strategies are investigated: nearest neighbor and interpolation followed by generation. Results on
shown on MNIST, CIFAR10 and IVUS (Intravascular Ultrasound) datasets.

Detailed comments:                      
The proposed method works in two stages. First a VAE is trained using unannotated samples. In the
second stage, hard examples are found, in every iteration, in the latent space of the VAE and used
for sequential training. The sampling is done using the gradient of the objective function in the
latent space. The method makes sense, however the choice of space in which the sample selection is
being done is not well motivated or validated. The space could have been the original image space
(although given the high dimension, it would probably not work), or could have been any intermediate
feature space. Why was the space chosen to be the VAE latent space? Would it be possible to 
demonstrate some benefits of doing so, theoretically and empirically? 

The experiment section is relatively weak. The datasets used are relatively small and in two out of
the three datasets, the method does not improve. The dimension of the latent space is also
surprisingly small (2). While the main body of the paper describes the method with VAEs, the
experiments for the CIFAR10 dataset (where the results were in favor) were done 
\alpha-GAN.
LLM_1: The comment discusses a paper proposing a sequential selection method of adaptive training samples in latent spaces. It suggests that the chosen space for sample collection, V AE latent, lacks motivation and validation, and that alternative spaces could be explored. Additionally, experiments are considered weak due to small datasets and limited improvement in some cases. Finally, inconsistencies in model choice for certain datasets are noted.
LLM_2:
While the paper presents an interesting approach to sequential sample selection in adaptive latent training, there are some aspects that warrant further discussion. Specifically, it is unclear why the authors chose the VAE latent space as the primary setting for their method, particularly given the lack of explicit motivation or validation for this choice. Exploring alternative latent representations could provide valuable insights and help to establish a stronger foundation for the proposed approach. Moreover, some experiments appear limited by the use of small-scale datasets, which may not fully capture the method's potential benefits. Lastly, I noticed inconsistencies across model choices for different datasets; a more careful consideration of these choices might strengthen the overall results.

human: My parents are gone, this part of the trip is over. I realize I have been increasingly stressed for about 8 months knowing they were coming. I just wanted everything to go OK for them while here. But I dreaded all the 'Well so and so's GRANDCHILDREN...' talks. They seem to understand that it costs too much to do anything in life now a days. I have never made more than what my father made in 1973, and THEIR house payment was 185 bucks a month..while my RENT is 725....They are starting to understand the modern world.  It feels like something of a weight has been lifted, but I am so worn out that I slept in today. I need to finish the Jeep project and get rid of stuff I own. I have too many 'Things'. A lack of 'Things' gives one freedom. You don't need a big place to live, or all sorts of other things that go with it. Actually, besides 3 cars, I own less things now than probably ever before. I think maybe in 1984 I had about the same amount of ownership.  Speaking to a friend last night outside on the curb. A woman came out of her place to see if we were OK. Offered us wine..like an idiot I declined! Damn- I thought later she probably wanted someone to talk to! I was worried our talking had upset her so felt hurried to leave. I should have talked to HER. She was both young and attractive, and was listening to Enya in her living room. She had a dog...geez, am I blind, stupid or BOTH...?!?!!!?
LLM_1: After my parents' visit, I felt a mix of relief and exhaustion from the stress of wanting everything to go well. Their understanding of modern challenges, such as rising living costs, has improved. I realized I need to declutter my life, as owning fewer things brings freedom. Despite owning less now than in the past, I still feel burdened. I also regret declining a woman's invitation for conversation while hanging out with a friend, realizing too late that she might have wanted companionship.

Another pedestrian, a man in his 40s, remains in hospital in south London.

The crash came just months after another crash near the main entrance to the Friary Centre when a car hit pedestrians and left several people injured, including a toddler and his baby sister.
The collision happened in North Street last October.
Leader of Guildford Borough Council, Paul Spooner, said Saturday's accident was "tragic and saddening".
"We await the outcome of Surrey Police's investigation and until the full reasons are known it is impossible to comment on what the cause could be," he said.
"Although we don't know if the road layout contributed, the Town Centre Masterplan includes options for improving transport and pedestrian movements around the station area and Bridge Street."

human: Plant-based remedies continue to play a key role in the health care of people in Togo; however, there is a lack of published data in medicinal plants and medical practices of the people in the country.This study was aimed at documenting the plant utilization in the Tem folk medicine in the central region of Togo.An ethnobotanical survey was conducted with traditional healers in the central region of Togo using a semi-structured questionnaire.This study demonstrated that local specialists in the central region of Togo tend to agree with each other in terms of the plants used to treat diabetes (ICF = 0.38), infertility, and abdominal pains (ICF = 0.33), but cite a much more diverse groups of plants to treat problems related to arterial hypertension, sickle cell disease, and abscess. They use 144 herbal concoctions made of 72 plants, distributed among 36 botanical families. The Euphorbiaceae family with eight species was best represented in terms of the number of species. The species with the highest use value were Khaya senegalensis (Desr.) A. Juss. (Meliaceae) (UV = 0.36), Anthocleista djalonensis A. Chev. (Gentianaceae) (UV = 0.27), Trichilia emetica Vahl (Meliaceae) (UV = 0.25), and Sarcocephalus latifolius (Sm.) E. A. Bruce (Rubiaceae) (UV = 0.21). They also rely on the timing in the plant processing and the administration of herbal remedies.
LLM_1: An ethnobotanical study in central Togo documented Tem traditional medicine, revealing 144 herbal treatments from 72 plants across 36 families, with Euphorbiaceae most common. Healers showed strong consensus on plants for diabetes, infertility, and abdominal pain, but varied for hypertension, sickle cell disease, and abscesses. Key species included *Khaya senegalensis*, *Anthocleista djalonensis*, *Trichilia emetica*, and *Sarcocephalus latifolius*. Timing in preparation and administration was also crucial. The research addresses a gap in published data on Togo's medicinal plants.
LLM_2: An ethnobotanical investigation conducted in central Togo systematically documented traditional medicinal practices among the Tem ethnic group. The study cataloged 144 distinct herbal remedies derived from 72 plant species spanning 36 botanical families, with Euphorbiaceae identified as the most frequently represented family. Healer consensus was notably high for treatments targeting diabetes, infertility, and abdominal pain, whereas approaches for managing hypertension, sickle cell disease, and abscesses exhibited greater variability. Prominent medicinal species included *Khaya senegalensis*, *Anthocleista djalonensis*, *Trichilia emetica*, and *Sarcocephalus latifolius*. The timing of both preparation and administration of remedies emerged as a significant factor in therapeutic practices. This research contributes to filling a notable gap in the published literature on the medicinal flora of Togo.

human: so yesterday i was standing at the ice well making a vodka and cranberry. and for some reason i had a memory of the road. the memory i had was being at a shell station outside of Seattle somewhere in the mountains. we filled the truck up with gas and our stomaches with tacos. one of which found its way under the truck seat until monday(5days). whoops. anyhow it was a bright sunny day, i think there might have been some high clouds but not many. the trees were tall and green. and there were some rock n roll hippies. i have no other way to describe them. people who from a distance look like hippies; worn baggy clothes, long hair, and shabby shoes, but on closer inspection reveal themselves to be metal heads;a Dio baseball shirt or metallica tee, wallet chains and corduroy pants, and old nike shoes. on a side note, i wish that the chain-driven wallet had not gained so much popularity. i liked it when people looked at me with fear and disgust just because i wore a chain on my wallet. now every one from weekend bikers to 14 year old korn fans wear them. however, i'm a goober and if my wallet is not attached to my body then i would set it down somewhere and forget where i put it. also the reason that i have a hook on my keys. i haven't lost my keys since i put my them on the hook about 10 years ago. now that i'm saying this i'm probably gonna lose them.  so anyway back to the point, it was a nice memory to have yesterday. thinking of that warm fall day. me and my girl. on the road to seattle and self discovery. i just wonder what it was that triggered the memory..........
LLM_1: While making a drink, I recalled a sunny fall road trip near Seattle with my partner, stopping for gas and tacos. The scene included tall trees and rock-and-roll hippies—people who appeared hippie-like but wore metal band shirts and wallet chains. I reflected briefly on how wallet chains have become common, unlike when they once seemed edgy. The memory was pleasant but its trigger remains a mystery.
LLM_2:
The other day, I was mixing a drink when a memory washed over me—clear and sudden, like a sunbeam breaking through the clouds. It was from a crisp autumn afternoon a few years back, somewhere on a winding road outside Seattle. My partner and I were on one of those aimless, golden-hour drives that seem to exist outside of time. We pulled over for gas and, on a whim, grabbed tacos from a roadside stand.

What stuck with me wasn’t just the tacos or the scenery—though the towering evergreens against a bright blue sky were picture-perfect. It was the people. A group lounging near their cars looked like throwback hippies at first glance, but a second look revealed Metallica tees, worn-out jeans, and yes, wallet chains swinging from their pockets.

It got me thinking about how symbols shift over time. That wallet chain—once a badge of rebellion, a quiet “don’t mess with me” from the punk and metal scenes—now feels almost commonplace. A small, clinking accessory that’s lost a bit of its edge and found its way into everyday wear.

I still don’t know why that particular moment surfaced while I stood there, ice clinking in my glass. Some memories just appear, gentle and unannounced, leaving behind the quiet warmth of a sunlit afternoon and the faint echo of a chain softly clinking in the breeze.

human:
He had been a devout man all his life. Tough as it got sometimes, his base urges running rampant through his body, he stuck to his faith. His personal oath with something larger than man. His mind kept his body in check through long and painful years filled with loneliness and despair. Sometimes the promise of heaven being all keeping him upright, for suicide was a sure way down to hell. Stealing your gift from the lord. He had cared for the weak and supported the needy, mostly with little return. But in time, his time had come. And somewhere in his mind he was glad for the end. Society as he would have liked it had never existed on his earth. Civilisation without civility being a main issue he had had with life. Now, as he ascended the stairway to eternal bliss a smile cracked his face for the first time since the disease had started wrecking him. A kindly old man stood at the top of the path, nodding at him with a sagely smile. The man nodded back and walked up to him, extending a hand. The bearded man took his hand and gave it a firm shake. Mutely he was guided to a gate of gold and silver, which opened as they approached. The old man urged him on, he himself pausing at the edge of the gate. 
 
 With a small step he crossed the threshold. A grin splitting his face as he tried to see into the light that shone into hi face as the gate closed behind him. The light was fierce and stimulated his optical nerves to the point of sneezing. `` Odd.'' He said to himself, but he continued on as the light started to dim. His eyes getting used to the new environment. 
 
 
 It felt like someone was watching over his shoulder and he quickly turned. He felt old bones creak, and took the lords name in vain. Dumb thing to do, swearing in the actual house of the lord, was his thought. However all the lord did was turn up the light, illiciting another sneeze. 
 
 
 This brought the man a certain measure of relief. And he shrugged off the feeling of being watched. He started scouting around. Searching the endless plane of existence, but finding nothing and nobody. A voice suddenly started speaking in his mind. 
 
 `` I'm actually quite unsure of what to do with you. You are the first person to ever be admitted through the gate. As such, I can do naught but let you wait for another.'' 
 
 And so the man waited, for what felt like ages, and nobody ever came. Sadness seeping into his weary bones. He did not hunger or thirst, but this afterlife gave him no joy.
LLM_1: A devout man endured a difficult life of faith and self-denial, finding solace only in the hope of heaven. Upon his death, he ascended to an afterlife, greeted by a kindly figure at a magnificent gate. However, upon entering, he found himself alone in an empty, endless plane. A divine voice admitted he was the first to arrive and could only wait. He waited eternally in a joyless existence, with no others ever joining him.
LLM_2:
The man had lived a life of quiet devotion, his days a tapestry of small denials and steadfast faith, each thread woven with the promise of a greater reward. Earth had been a trial—a long, gray corridor at the end of which, he was certain, a door would open onto light, warmth, and communion.

When the end came, it felt less like an ending and more like a gentle lifting. He found himself standing before a gate of shimmering pearl, vast and radiant. A being of soft light welcomed him with a smile that held the warmth of a forgotten sun. “Enter,” it seemed to say without words. Heart swelling with a relief he had spent a lifetime imagining, he stepped through.

And into silence.

The gate did not open onto fields of gold or choirs of voices. It opened onto an expanse—blank, pale, and perfect, stretching into forever in every direction. The light was even, shadowless, and cold. He was utterly alone.

A voice then filled the emptiness, not from above or around, but from within the very fabric of the void. It was calm, clear, and without malice.
“You are the first.”
The words hung in the sterile air.
“You may wait.”

And so, he waited. Eternity unspooled before him, featureless and still. He waited for the sound of a footstep, the murmur of a second voice, the glow of another soul arriving through the glorious gate. He waited for the joy he had been promised, for the community of the faithful, for the meaning of his long endurance.

But no one ever came. The magnificent gate stood silent behind him, a monument to an arrival that had become its own conclusion. The heaven he had earned was not punishment, nor was it paradise. It was an endless, quiet anteroom—a perfect, empty peace where a devout man waited, forever, for heaven to begin.

human:
It has to be hot for the devil to appear. And the summer is hot in Rosedale, Mississippi. There was no breeze, bullfrogs croaked in the mud, and ten men stood silent in a dark field. 
 
 `` Boy, what ai n't you telling us?'' The voice was deep like bass and rolled through the humid night like thunder. 
 
 `` I tell ya, you just wait right here. He be here real soon.'' Robert Johnson tried hard to hide the nervousness in his voice. It was n't easy to get nine men out to the crossroad at night and he was n't going to spook them off now. 
 
 `` And you say he will pay us good?'' Another voice whispered out to Robert. 
 
 Robert looked at the ragged men sitting to the side of the gravel road. He thanked God they were poor. Ai n't no other reason to be out in these fields at night, unless money is at stake. `` He gone pay you boys real good. Ai n't no worries.'' 
 
 `` Why we meet him at night?'' 
 
 `` Why you got so many damn question!'' Robert's voice carried an edge to it. `` Ai n't a one of you boys got somewhere better to be!'' 
 
 The sounds of the southern night took over again. The crickets chorused and a lone owl hooted out a warning cry. Robert sit down with his guitar and began to strum a few chords, eerie in the still night. A fog bank rolled in from four corners of the cotton fields and crept low toward the crossroads. The owl called out again. 
 
 The men were getting jumpy. The deep voice said from the dark, `` Something ai n't right. I do n't like it.'' 
 
 Robert could see the fear in their eyes as the moon came out from hiding. `` It's too late now. It's midnight and he's a coming.'' 
 
 Robert Johnson sat by the roadside and sang: 
 
 Early this morning 
 When you knocked upon my door 
 Early this morning, ooh 
 When you knocked upon my door 
 And I said `` Hello Satan 
 I believe it's time to go''
LLM_1: On a hot, still summer night in Rosedale, Mississippi, Robert Johnson brings nine skeptical, impoverished men to a crossroads, promising them payment from a mysterious figure. Tension rises as fog rolls in and eerie sounds fill the air. Despite their fear and doubts, Robert insists it’s too late to turn back—midnight has come, and Satan is arriving. He begins to sing a haunting song greeting Satan, signaling the fulfillment of his fateful pact.
LLM_2:
Beneath a swollen, breathless moon on a summer night in Rosedale, Mississippi, the air hangs thick and unmoving, as if the world itself is holding its breath. Crickets have gone silent. Even the river seems to creep slower through the dark. Here, at the crooked seam of two forgotten roads, Robert Johnson stands with nine ragged men—each one hollow-eyed, desperate, their souls already half-mortgaged to hunger and hard luck.

They came for silver. For salvation. For something—anything—to break the back of their sorrow. Robert promised them a meeting. A transaction. A voice from beyond the veil, willing to pay in power instead of coin.

Now, as a spectral fog coils up from the cracked earth like smoke from a buried fire, doubt begins to gnaw at them. Whispers skitter between the trees. A hound howls—not far off, but not quite near either—and the sound twists wrong before it fades. One man crosses himself. Another grips a pocketknife so tight his knuckles gleam.

But Robert only smiles.

It’s past turning back now, he says. The clock has bled into midnight. The deal was made long ago, in blood and silence, and the hour has come round like a wheel.

Then he sings.

His voice spills low and liquid into the dark—a melody that doesn’t belong to this world, a hymn turned inside out. It curls through the mist like an invitation, a key turning in a rusted lock. *Hello, Devil*, the notes seem to say. *I’ve been waiting.*

And somewhere deep in the black between the trees, something answers—not in words, but in weight, in presence, in the sudden stillness that follows the last echo of the song.

The bargain is sealed.

The crossroads trembles.

And Robert Johnson, clutching his guitar like a holy relic, knows he no longer walks among men.

human: Matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP-2) is responsible for the degradation of various types of extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins such as type IV collagen. Decreased MMP-2 expression and activity has been generally thought to contribute to increased accumulation of ECM at the advanced stage of diabetic nephropathy. However, the kinetics and role of MMP-2 in the early phase of diabetic nephropathy remain unclear. To address this issue, we examined whether streptozotocin (STZ)-induced early diabetic nephropathy was accelerated in MMP-2 knockout (KO) mice.Diabetes was induced by the injection of STZ in 6-week-old control and MMP-2 KO mice. Animals were killed after 16 weeks of diabetes of after observation alone.Compared with non-diabetic control mice, renal MMP-2 expression and activity were increased in 16-week old diabetic mice. Serum levels of blood urea nitrogen and creatinine and urinary excretion levels of albumin and N-acetyl-β-D-glucosaminidase were significantly elevated in diabetic MMP-2 KO mice when compared with wild-type diabetic littermates. Further, accumulation of ECM in the glomeruli and atrophy and fibrosis in the tubulointerstitium were exacerbated, and renal α-smooth muscle actin expression was enhanced in diabetic MMP-2 KO mice.
LLM_1: Increased renal MMP-2 expression and activity in early diabetic nephropathy protect against kidney damage, as MMP-2 knockout mice with STZ-induced diabetes show worse renal function, greater ECM accumulation, glomerular and tubulointerstitial injury, and elevated fibrosis markers compared to wild-type diabetic mice.
LLM_2:
**Polished Version:**

Elevated renal matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP-2) expression and activity in early diabetic nephropathy appear to exert protective effects against kidney injury. In streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice, MMP-2 deficiency exacerbates renal dysfunction, extracellular matrix accumulation, glomerular and tubulointerstitial damage, and fibrosis marker expression compared to wild-type diabetic controls, suggesting a renoprotective role for MMP-2 in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy.

Let me know if you'd like a shorter or more technical variation depending on journal requirements.

Hewlett, who died following a diagnosis of cancer of the oesophagus in 2016, movingly shared his experience of coping with his illness on BBC Radio 4.
He had fronted the show since 2008.
Rajan said: "I have been addicted to The Media Show for years and am genuinely humbled at the prospect of sitting in Steve Hewlett's chair.
"He was a giant of broadcasting and I will do my utmost to maintain the very high standards he achieved."
Hewlett's interviews with Eddie Mair on Radio 4's PM offered insight into his cancer journey, examining issues such as drug trials and reaction to treatment.
The Media Show is Radio 4's weekly look back at the latest stories and trends across the media industry both at home and abroad, and Rajan will make his debut on 10 May.
As well as being the BBC's media editor, he has deputised for Jeremy Vine and Simon Mayo on Radio 2, appeared on BBC One's Masterchef, presented episodes of Radio 4's Start the Week and Any Answers and is one of the hosts of Asian Network's The Big Debate. Rajan is also a former editor of The Independent.
Andrea Catherwood will continue to present some editions of the programme.
Follow us on Facebook, on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, or on Instagram at bbcnewsents. If you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.
LLM_1: Steve Hewlett, a respected broadcaster who died in 2016, openly discussed his cancer journey on BBC Radio 4. Amol Rajan, the BBC's media editor and former Independent editor, will take over hosting The Media Show from May 10, aiming to uphold Hewlett's legacy. The program reviews weekly media industry developments.
LLM_2:
**Respected Broadcaster’s Legacy to Continue on BBC Radio 4’s *The Media Show***

Steve Hewlett, the esteemed broadcaster who passed away in 2016 after candidly sharing his experience with cancer on BBC Radio 4, will see his legacy carried forward by a new host. Amol Rajan, the BBC’s Media Editor and former editor of *The Independent*, is set to take the helm of *The Media Show* beginning May 10.

The program, which provides weekly analysis and discussion of key developments across the media industry, will continue under Rajan’s stewardship. The appointment signals the BBC’s commitment to maintaining the thoughtful, incisive tone that Hewlett established—a tone that resonated deeply with listeners during his personal and professional reflections on air.

Rajan, known for his sharp editorial insight and extensive background in journalism, is expected to build on the show’s reputation for exploring media trends, ethics, and industry shifts with both depth and clarity.

*The Media Show* airs on BBC Radio 4.
